case_name: C.A. Nos. 323-332, 1312, 1174 of 1969 and connected appeals

facts.text: Appeals numbered C.A. Nos. 323-332, 1312, 1174 of 1969 were filed by certificate from the judgment and decree dated September 27, 1968 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court.

anchor.surface_text: C.A. Nos. 323-332, 1312 1174 of 1969. Appeals by certificate from the judgment and a decree dated September 27, 1968 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court of Judicature at Hyderabad in Writ Petitions Nos. 2956, 1798, 1931, 2313, 3372, 3740, 3964, 3956 and 4088 of 1968

facts.text: Judgment and decree dated September 27, 1968 delivered by Andhra Pradesh High Court in Writ Petitions Nos. 2956, 1798, 1931, 2313, 3372, 3740, 3964, 3956 and 4088 of 1968.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1518 of 1970 on appeal by certificate from judgment and order dated March 31, 1970 of Andhra Pradesh High Court in Writ Petition No. 3501 of 1968.

anchor.surface_text: and Civil Appeal No. 1518 of 1970. On appeal by certificate from the judgment and order dated March 31, 1970, of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in Writ Petition No. 3501 of 1968 and Appeal by certificate against the judgment and order dated August 25, 1970

facts.text: Appeal by certificate against judgment and order dated August 25, 1970 of Andhra Pradesh High Court in Writ Petition No. 4034 of 1970.

anchor.surface_text: of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in Writ Petition No. 3501 of 1968 and Appeal by certificate against the judgment and order dated August 25, 1970 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court of Judicature at Hyderabad in Writ Petition No. 4034 of 1970.

facts.text: Each of the appellants is a miller who applied to the High Court of Andhra Pradesh under Article 226 for a Writ of Prohibition against sales-tax assessment proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: Each of the appellants before us is a miller and one of a large number of such millers who had applied to the High Court of Andhra Pradesh, under Article 226 of the Constitution, for a Writ of Prohibition against proceedings for assessment of Sales-Tax

facts.text: Validity of item 6 of Schedule III of the Andhra Pradesh General Sales Tax Act, 6 of 1957 challenged in High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The validity of item 6 of Schedule III of the Act was challenged on a number of grounds in the High Court which need number be mentioned here

facts.text: Only ground argued before Supreme Court is whether item 6 of Schedule III contravenes Section 15(a) of Central Sales Tax Act, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: as the only ground which has been argued before us is companyered by the question formulated above.

facts.text: Appellants are registered as dealers under the Act and Central Act.

anchor.surface_text: the extent, if any, to which each petitioner, who is a miller, registered also as a dealer under the Act as well as under the Central Act, sells groundnuts,

facts.text: Some petitioners purchased groundnuts specifically for crushing into oil or other product.

anchor.surface_text: or, whether groundnuts were purchased specifically only for purposes of crushing them and companyverting them into oil or into any other product or for the purpose of sale as well.

facts.text: Item 6 of Schedule III levies tax on groundnuts at 3 naya paise in the rupee when purchased by a miller other than decorticating miller at point of purchase by such miller.

anchor.surface_text: Item 6 of Schedule III reads as follows Description of goods-- Point of levy Rate of tax Groundnuts 3 naya paise in the rupee When purchased by a miller other than a decorticating miller in the State at the point of purchase by such miller, and, in all other cases at the point of purchase by the last.

facts.text: Groundnuts declared as goods of special importance in inter-state trade under Section 14 of Central Sales Tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: Groundnuts have been declared as goods of special importance in inter-state trade or companymerce under Section 14 of the Central Act.

facts.text: Section 15(a) of Central Act restricts state tax on declared goods to not exceed 3% and not levied at more than one stage.

anchor.surface_text: Section 15 of the Central Act lays down Every sales tax law of a State shall, in so far as it imposes or authorises the imposition of a tax on the sale or purchase of declared goods, be subject to the following restrictions and companyditions, namely  a  the tax payable under that law in respect of any sale or purchase of such goods inside the State shall number exceed three per cent of the sale or purchase Price thereof, and such tax shall number be levied at more than one stage

facts.text: Andhra Pradesh High Court gave relief to appellants on rate of tax under item 6 because turnover definition includes more than sale price.

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned that, in so far as the rate of tax specified in item 6, Schedule III of the Act is companycerned, the Andhra Pradesh High Court had itself given some relief to the appellants, on the ground that the definition of turn-over under the Act companyld include what is more than the sale price as defined by the Central Act,

facts.text: Appellants contend that groundnuts purchased by them taxed at point of purchase by millers and again by last dealers to whom they sell.

anchor.surface_text: It is companytended that the groundnuts purchased by the appel- lants would be taxed at the point of purchase by them and also again in the hands of last dealers to whom they may sell.

facts.text: Appellants purchase groundnuts as millers to convert into another product and are last purchasers of groundnuts.

anchor.surface_text: When they purchase groundnuts as millers they do so presumably in order to companyvert the groundnuts into another product altogether, and, they would, therefore, presumably be last purchasers of ground-nuts as groundnuts.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeals after hearing.

anchor.surface_text: We have already dismissed the appeals after hearing them. We number proceed to record our reasons.

facts.text: Issue covered by prior Supreme Court decision in Sri Venkateswara Rice, Ginning Groundnut Oil Mill Contractors Co. etc. v. State of A.P.

anchor.surface_text: In fact, the question raised before us seems to us to be companyered by a decision of this Court on item 6 of Schedule III in Sri Venkateswara Rice, Ginning Groundnut Oil Mill Contractors Co. etc. v. The, State of A. P. Ors.  1  where this Court said at page 5 3

facts.text: None of the assessees in prior case were decorticating millers.

anchor.surface_text: None of the assessees before us is a decorticating miller. Hence we have to see whether the purchases of groundnut made by, them did number become taxable as soon as they made those purchases.

facts.text: Purchases of groundnuts by millers become taxable at the point of purchase.

anchor.surface_text: Hence the turnover relating to the purchases with which we are companycerned in these appeals became charged with the liability to pay tax as soon as those purchases were made by the assessee-millers.

facts.text: In prior case, argument that part of groundnuts sold to other millers should be taxed only at last dealer rejected.

anchor.surface_text: The next argument advanced on behalf of the assessees is that in the case of some of the assessees a part of the groundnut purchased had, been sold to other millers hence in those cases, the assessees must be taxed only in respect of that part of the turnover which relates to groundnut which they had crushed for extracting oil and in the case of remaining part, it is the last dealer who purchased the same should be taxed.

facts.text: Tax liability attracted by act of miller purchasing groundnuts, subsequent dealings irrelevant.

anchor.surface_text: As mentioned earlier the event which attracted tax is the act of the miller purchasing groundnut and number his act of crushing the groundnut purchased or dealing with that groundnut in any other manner.

facts.text: None of the assessees in prior cases purchased groundnuts with view to sell them.

anchor.surface_text: In numbere of the cases before us it was shown that any of. the assessees had pur- chased groundnut with a view to sell them.

facts.text: No possibility of double taxation or taxation at more than one point.

anchor.surface_text: We were number satisfied that there is a possibility of double taxation or of taxation of the same product at more than one point of purchase.

issues.text: Is any part of the provision of Item 6 of Schedule III of the Andhra Pradesh General Sales Tax Act 6 of 1957 hereinafter referred to as the Act relating to the point of levy void for contravening Section 15(a) of the Central Sales Tax Act, 1956?

anchor.surface_text: Is any part of the provision of Item 6 of Schedule III of the Andhra Pradesh General Sales Tax Act  6 of 1957   hereinafter referred to as the Act  relating to the point of levy void for contravening Section 15  a  of the Central Sales Tax Act, 1956 ?

arguments.claim: Tax charge under sales tax laws attaches immediately upon purchase by miller, computation later; liability exigible as soon as purchase made

anchor.surface_text: None of the assessees before us is a decorticating miller. Hence we have to see whether the purchases of groundnut made by, them did become taxable as soon as they made those purchases. it is not well settled that even under the Sales Tax laws, the charge in respect of a sale or purchase becomes effective as soon as the sale in the case of purchase tax is made, though the liability of the dealer can be computed only at the end of the year.

arguments.court_reasoning: Event attracting tax is purchase by miller, not crushing or subsequent dealing; liability under S.5 r/w Sch III Item 6 on purchase

arguments.claim: Event attracting tax liability is act of miller purchasing groundnuts, not crushing or other subsequent dealings

anchor.surface_text: As mentioned earlier the event which attracted tax is the act of the miller purchasing groundnut and not his act of crushing the groundnut purchased or dealing with that groundnut in any other manner. We have earlier mentioned that very act of purchase by a miller attracts the liability to pay tax under Section 5 read with Schedule 3 item 6.

arguments.claim: No possibility of double taxation or taxation at more than one point under Item 6

anchor.surface_text: We were not satisfied that there is a possibility of double taxation or of taxation of the same product at more than one point of purchase.

holdings.text: No part of the provision of Item 6 of Schedule III of the Andhra Pradesh General Sales Tax Act relating to the point of levy is void for contravening Section 15(a) of the Central Sales Tax Act, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Is any part of the provision of Item 6 of Schedule III of the Andhra Pradesh General Sales Tax Act  6 of 1957   hereinafter referred to as the Act  relating to the point of levy void for contravening Section 15  a  of the Central Sales Tax Act, 1956 ?

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tax levied only at single point of purchase by miller who is last purchaser of groundnuts; no multi-stage taxation; follows prior Supreme Court precedent; subsequent dealings irrelevant.

holdings.text: Millers purchase groundnuts to convert into another product and are therefore the last purchasers of groundnuts as such.

anchor.surface_text: When they purchase groundnuts as millers they do so presumably in order to convert the groundnuts into another product altogether, and, they would, therefore, presumably be last purchasers of ground-nuts as groundnuts.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purpose of miller's purchase is conversion, not resale as groundnuts, making them last purchasers for tax point.

holdings.text: The charge of tax under sales tax laws becomes effective as soon as the purchase is made by the miller, though computation occurs later.

anchor.surface_text: None of the assessees before us is a decorticating miller. Hence we have to see whether the purchases of groundnut made by, them did become taxable as soon as they made those purchases. it is now well settled that even under the Sales Tax laws, the charge in respect of a sale or purchase becomes effective as soon as the sale in the case of purchase tax is made, though the liability of the dealer can be computed only at the end of the year.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Well-settled principle applied: liability attaches immediately on purchase by assessee-millers.

holdings.text: The event attracting tax liability is the purchase of groundnuts by the miller; subsequent crushing or other dealings are irrelevant.

anchor.surface_text: As mentioned earlier the event which attracted tax is the act of the miller purchasing groundnut and not his act of crushing the groundnut purchased or dealing with that groundnut in any other manner. We have earlier mentioned that very act of purchase by a miller attracts the liability to pay tax under Section 5 read with Schedule 3 item 6. His subsequent dealings in those goods become irrelevant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects petitioner argument on partial sales to other millers; tax triggered by purchase act per statute.

holdings.text: There is no possibility of double taxation or taxation of the same product at more than one point of purchase under Item 6.

anchor.surface_text: We were not satisfied that there is a possibility of double taxation or of taxation of the same product at more than one point of purchase.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Scheme ensures single point levy at miller purchase; no evidence of resale intent by assessees.

holdings.text: The question is covered by the prior Supreme Court decision in Sri Venkateswara Rice etc. v. State of A.P.

anchor.surface_text: In fact, the question raised before us seems to us to be covered by a decision of this Court on item 6 of Schedule III in Sri Venkateswara Rice, Ginning Groundnut Oil Mill Contractors Co. etc. v. The, State of A. P. Ors.  1  where this Court said at page 5 3

holdings.reasoning_summary: Directly applies binding precedent upholding same provision.

precedents.citation: Sri Venkateswara Rice, Ginning Groundnut Oil Mill Contractors Co. etc. v. The, State of A. P. Ors.  1  A.I.R. 1972 S.C.51.

anchor.surface_text: Sri Venkateswara Rice, Ginning Groundnut Oil Mill Contractors Co. etc. v. The, State of A. P. Ors.  1  where this Court said at page 5 3 None of the assessees before us is a decorticating miller. Hence we have to see whether the purchases of groundnut made by, them did number become taxable as soon as they made those purchases. it is number well settled that even under the Sales Tax laws, the charge in respect of a sale or purchase becomes effective as soon as the sale in the case of purchase tax is made, though the liability of the dealer can be companyputed only at the end of the year. The incurring of the charge is one thing and its companyputation is a totally different A.I.R. 1972 S.C.51.

precedents.case_name: Sri Venkateswara Rice Ginning Groundnut Oil Mill Contractors Co. v. State of A.P.
precedents.cited_proposition: Purchases of groundnuts by millers other than decorticating millers attract tax liability at the point of purchase, constituting a single stage of taxation under Item 6 of Schedule III, and the charge becomes effective immediately upon purchase.
precedents.cited_holding: None of the assessees before us is a decorticating miller. Hence we have to see whether the purchases of groundnut made by, them did number become taxable as soon as they made those purchases... the turnover relating to that purchase... becomes liable to tax... the event which attracted tax is the act of the miller purchasing groundnut.

h4 states event attracting tax liability is purchase by miller, core to c7
Narrow holding h4 on purchase event supports h1 upholding provision as constitutional under single reasonable interpretation.

anchor.surface_text: As mentioned earlier the event which attracted tax is the act of the miller purchasing groundnut and not his act of crushing the groundnut purchased or dealing with that groundnut in any other manner. We have earlier mentioned that very act of purchase by a miller attracts the liability to pay tax under Section 5 read with Schedule 3 item 6. His subsequent dealings in those goods become irrelevant.
We have already dismissed the appeals after hearing them.

anchor.surface_text: We were not satisfied that there is a possibility of double taxation or of taxation of the same product at more than one point of purchase.
